title: The Disk Wipe: A dd Horror Story
scenario: A system administrator wants to create a bootable USB drive. They accidentally target the wrong device with dd if=/dev/zero.

timeline.description: Admin runs: dd if=/dev/zero of=/dev/sda (meant to use /dev/sdb for USB)
dd starts writing zeros to /dev/sda (the main hard drive!)
Boot sector overwritten with zeros. System can no longer boot.
Partition table destroyed. Operating system can't find any partitions.
Admin notices something wrong: 'Why is this taking so long?'
Admin checks: 'lsblk' shows /dev/sda being written to. Panic sets in.
Admin hits Ctrl+C to stop dd. But it's too late - first 10GB already zeroed.
Admin tries to reboot. System shows: 'No bootable device found'
Data recovery specialist consulted. Verdict: 'Boot sector and OS files are gone. Some data might be recoverable.'
Recovery cost: $1,500. Only 40% of data recovered. System must be rebuilt from scratch.
Admin learns: Always double-check device names. Use 'lsblk' before dd. Consider using 'pv' to see progress.

outcome: One typo (sda instead of sdb) cost $1,500 in recovery fees, 60% data loss, and a week of downtime. The dd command earned its nickname: 'disk destroyer'.
lessons_learned: dd is called 'disk destroyer' for a reason - it's unforgiving
Always use 'lsblk' to verify device names before using dd
The 'of=' parameter is what gets destroyed - triple-check it
Consider using 'pv' with dd to see progress and have time to cancel
One character difference (sda vs sdb) can destroy your entire system
Practice dd commands on virtual machines or test systems first
